TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed beforefieldinit DesignerSerializationVisibilityAttribute extends System.Attribute

Docs.summary: Specifies the type of persistence to use when serializing a property on a component at design time.

remarks.format:
## Remarks When a serializer persists the persistable state of a design mode document, it often adds code to the initialization method of components to persist values of properties that have been set at design time. This happens by default for most basic types, if no attribute has been set to direct other behavior.
With the DesignerSerializationVisibilityAttribute, you can indicate whether the value for a property is <xref:System.ComponentModel.DesignerSerializationVisibilityAttribute.Visible>, and should be persisted in initialization code, <xref:System.ComponentModel.DesignerSerializationVisibilityAttribute.Hidden>, and should not be persisted in initialization code, or consists of <xref:System.ComponentModel.DesignerSerializationVisibilityAttribute.Content>, which should have initialization code generated for each public, not hidden property of the object assigned to the property.
Members that do not have a DesignerSerializationVisibilityAttribute will be treated as though they have a DesignerSerializationVisibilityAttribute with a value of <xref:System.ComponentModel.DesignerSerializationVisibility>. The values of a property marked as <xref:System.ComponentModel.DesignerSerializationVisibility> will be serialized, if possible, by a serializer for the type. To specify custom serialization for a particular type or property, use the <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.Serialization.DesignerSerializerAttribute>.
For more information, see [Attributes](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the use of a DesignerSerializationVisibilityAttribute set to <xref:System.ComponentModel.DesignerSerializationVisibility>. It persists the values of a public property of a user control, which can be configured at design time. To use the example, first compile the following code into a user control library. Next, add a reference to the compiled .dll file in a new Windows Application project. If you are using [!INCLUDE[vsprvs](~/add/includes/vsprvs-md.md)], the `ContentSerializationExampleControl` is automatically added to the **Toolbox**.
Drag the control from the **Toolbox** to a form, and set the properties of the `DimensionData` object listed in the Properties window. When you view the code for the form, code will have been added to the `InitializeComponent` method of the parent form. This code sets the values of the control's properties to those which you have set in design mode.
[!code-cpp[Classic DesignerSerializationVisibilityAttribute Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/t-system.componentmodel._115_1.cpp)] [!code-cs[Classic DesignerSerializationVisibilityAttribute Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/t-system.componentmodel._115_1.cs)] [!code-vb[Classic DesignerSerializationVisibilityAttribute Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/t-system.componentmodel._115_1.vb)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(valuetype System.ComponentModel.DesignerSerializationVisibility visibility) cil managed

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class using the specified value.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example specifies how a property on a component is saved by a designer. This code creates a new <xref:System.ComponentModel.DesignerSerializationVisibilityAttribute> and sets its value to <xref:System.ComponentModel.DesignerSerializationVisibilityAttribute.Content?displayProperty=fullName>.
[!code-vb[Classic DesignerSerializationVisibilityAttribute.DesignerSerializationVisibilityAttribute Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/071dd2e6-b07a-4262-963a-_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[Classic DesignerSerializationVisibilityAttribute.DesignerSerializationVisibilityAttribute Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/071dd2e6-b07a-4262-963a-_1.cpp)] [!code-cs[Classic DesignerSerializationVisibilityAttribute.DesignerSerializationVisibilityAttribute Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/071dd2e6-b07a-4262-963a-_1.cs)]

Docs.summary: Specifies that a serializer should serialize the contents of the property, rather than the property itself. This field is read-only.

remarks.format: ## Remarks When you mark a property with `DesignerSerializationVisibilityAttribute.Content`, the value of its <xref:System.ComponentModel.DesignerSerializationVisibilityAttribute.Visibility%2A> property is set to Content.

Docs.summary: Specifies the default value, which is , that is, a visual designer uses default rules to generate the value of a property. This field is read-only.

remarks.format: ## Remarks When you mark a property with this value, this attribute is set to the constant member <xref:System.ComponentModel.DesignerSerializationVisibilityAttribute>. Therefore, when you want to check whether the attribute is set to this value in your code, you must specify the attribute as <xref:System.ComponentModel.DesignerSerializationVisibilityAttribute?displayProperty=fullName>.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig virtual instance int32 GetHashCode() cil managed

Docs.summary: Returns the hash code for this object.
Specifies that a serializer should not serialize the value of the property. This field is read-only.

remarks.format: ## Remarks When you mark a property with `DesignerSerializationVisibilityAttribute.Hidden`, the value of its <xref:System.ComponentModel.DesignerSerializationVisibilityAttribute.Visibility%2A> property is set to the constant member Hidden.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig virtual instance bool IsDefaultAttribute() cil managed

Docs.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the current value of the attribute is the default value for the attribute.
Docs.returns: if the attribute is set to the default value; otherwise, .

Docs.summary: Gets a value indicating the basic serialization mode a serializer should use when determining whether and how to persist the value of a property.
Docs.value: One of the values. The default is .

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example shows how to check the value of the <xref:System.ComponentModel.DesignerSerializationVisibilityAttribute> for `MyProperty`. First the code gets a <xref:System.ComponentModel.PropertyDescriptorCollection> with all the properties for the object. Next, the code indexes into the <xref:System.ComponentModel.PropertyDescriptorCollection> to get `MyProperty`. Then, the code returns the attributes for this property and saves them in the attributes variable.
This example presents two different ways to check the value of the <xref:System.ComponentModel.DesignerSerializationVisibilityAttribute>. In the second code fragment, the example calls the <xref:System.Object.Equals%2A> method with a `static` value. In the last code fragment, the example uses the Visibility property to check the value.
[!code-cs[Classic DesignerSerializationVisibilityAttribute.Visibility Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/p-system.componentmodel._8_1.cs)] [!code-vb[Classic DesignerSerializationVisibilityAttribute.Visibility Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/p-system.componentmodel._8_1.vb)] [!code-cpp[Classic DesignerSerializationVisibilityAttribute.Visibility Example#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/p-system.componentmodel._8_1.cpp)]

Docs.summary: Specifies that a serializer should be allowed to serialize the value of the property. This field is read-only.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This field is the default setting for this attribute.
When you mark a property with `DesignerSerializationVisibilityAttribute.Visible`, the value of its `Visibility` property is set to the constant member Visible.
